data.title: Abbotsford’s James Lepp survives first qualifier in U.S. Open quest
data.meta_description: James Lepp has never played Chambers Bay Golf Course, but that could change come next month.
data.text:
James Lepp has never played Chambers Bay Golf Course, but that could change come next month.

Article content

VANCOUVER — James Lepp has never played Chambers Bay Golf Course, but that could change come next month.

The Abbotsford pro dusted off his golf game on Monday and took what he hopes is the first of two steps toward qualifying for the 115th playing of the U.S. Open. Lepp needed to work a little overtime to survive a local qualifier at The Home Course in Dupont, Wash. After posting an even-par round of 72, Lepp had to survive a seven-man playoff for the final two of seven spots that were up for grabs.

Article content

He now advances to sectional qualifying on June 8. If Lepp gets through that, he earns a spot in the field at Chambers Bay, the links course overlooking Puget Sound near Tacoma that will play host to the U.S. Open from June 18-21.

Lepp turned pro after a brilliant amateur career that included the 2005 NCAA Championship while he was earning a business degree at the University of Washington. He had some early success as a pro, but struggled with the mental side of his game.

Lepp has had an on-and-off relationship with the game in recent years and has devoted most of his energy to running his online golf shoe and apparel business, Kikkor Golf.

The fact the U.S. Open is being played nearby influenced his decision to try to qualify.

“I guess the fact the U.S. Open is local made everyone think about it a little more this year and I haven’t tried to qualify for a while,” Lepp said Tuesday. “I figured why not?

“I have never played it (Chambers Bay). I have been on the grounds before and had a chance to play it, but it was kind of snowing and I decided I’d rather not.”

Lepp, who does not play a whole lot of golf these days, warmed up for Monday’s qualifier in a rather unique way.

Article content

“I just had my stag in Palm Desert,” said Lepp, who is getting married in July.

“So I played all last weekend and then I was practising a little bit after that. I don’t practise that much and I actually practised quite a bit one day and I tore my hands apart so I couldn’t hold a club for a couple of days … But it ended up working out OK.”

The Home Course, long and wide open off the tee, suited Lepp’s game. But the pins were set in some tricky locations, which made it play tough.

“You have to try really hard to get into trouble off the tee,” Lepp said.

“So the only way they can really defend it is to put crazy pins out there. But the greens were really firm, so it was tough to get anything close to the hole.”

Lepp, who birdied his first two holes of the day, also birdied the first playoff hole to grab the first of the two available spots.

He expects to play his 36-hole sectional qualifier at Tumble Creek Golf Club at the Suncadia Resort in Cle Elum, Wash. This will be his second trip to sectional qualifying. He failed to advance in 2005 when he was awarded a spot in the sectionals after his NCAA Championship win.

Fellow B.C. pros Nick Taylor, Adam Hadwin and Roger Sloan, as PGA Tour members, were exempt through local qualifying and have spots in sectional qualifiers.

CHIP SHOTS: On Tuesday, Victoria’s Cory Renfrew advanced to sectional qualifying when he shot a six-under 66 to win a local qualifier in Durham, N.C.
